questions.question: Which malarial parasite has the shortest incubation period?
A patient from a hilly area was diagnosed with malaria. Which vector is most likelyresponsible for this?
questions.explanation: Anopheles fluviatilis is the vector for transmitting malaria in hilly areas, forests and forest fringes.VectorAreaAnopheles stephensi UrbanAnopheles culicifacies RuralAnopheles fluviatilis Hilly areas and forests

questions.question: Individuals with Duffy negative RBCs are resistant to:
questions.explanation: People with Duffy negative RBCs are resistant to P. vivax.Resistance to P.falciparum is seen in:• Individuals with sickle cell trait• Neonates, as fetal hemoglobin suppresses the development of P. falciparum

questions.question: Which is the most sensitive index of recent transmission of malaria?
questions.explanation: The infant parasite rate is regarded as the most sensitive index for recent transmission of malariain a locality.It is defined as the % of infants showing malarial parasites in their blood films. The transmissionof malaria is considered absent if the infant parasite rate is zero for 3 consecutive years in alocality (even though the Anopheline vectors responsible for the previous transmission mayremain).

questions.question: In a town with a population of 1,00,000, a total of 50,000 slides were examined for malaria.Among these, 100 cases of malaria were confirmed. What is the annual parasite incidence ofthis town?
questions.explanation: The annual parasite incidence of this town (API) is 1.API = Confirmed cases in a yearX 1000273Population under surveillanceIn this scenario, API = 100 x 1000/100000 = 1API is based on the number of slide-confirmed cases that are found through active and passivesurveillance. It is a measure of malaria incidence in a community and helps in determining theburden of the disease. Areas with API ≥ 2 / 1000 population are classified as high-risk areas andare eligible for vector control.Note: The number of slides examined is used to determine the annual blood examination rate(ABER).

questions.question: Which parameter is used to measure the operational efficiency of the National Vector BorneDisease Control Programme?
questions.explanation: The annual blood examination rate (ABER) is used to measure the operational efficiency of theNational Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP).

questions.question: A 44-year-old woman from Assam presented with fever and chills recurring every 48 hours.On examination, she was conscious, oriented, and febrile. CBC, LFT, and RFT were normal.Peripheral smear revealed the following. What is the drug of choice?267
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing crescent-shaped gametocytes are suggestiveof uncomplicated falciparum malaria. As this woman is from a North-Eastern state, the drugregimen of choice is ACT-AL (artemisinin combination therapy):••• Artemether (20mg)• Lumefantrine (120mg)This regimen is followed in the North-Eastern states of India due to documented resistanceto sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine in these areas. ACT-AL is contraindicated in:• 1st trimester of pregnancy• Children < 5 kg

questions.question: A 23-year-old pregnant woman at 11 weeks of gestation was diagnosed with falciparummalaria. What is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation: Quinine is the drug of choice for falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy.The treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy is as follows:• 1st trimester - quinine•2nd and 3rd trimester - ACT-AL in North-Eastern states and ACT-SP in other states

questions.question: Which of the following patients with malaria can be treated with primaquine?

options.A: A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation
options.B: A 10-year-old boy diagnosed with G6PD deficiency
options.C: A 40-year-old woman recently treated for a flare-up of SLE
options.D: A 60-year-old man who had a myocardial infarction 4 months ago268

questions.explanation: Cardiac disease is not a contraindication for the use of primaquine. It is contraindicated in:274• Infants•Pregnant and lactating women• Patients with G6PD deficiency• Patients at risk of developing granulocytopenia:•Systemic diseases including active RA and SLE• Drugs that cause hemolysis or bone marrow depression

questions.question: What is the dose of mefloquine given for chemoprophylaxis of malaria?
questions.explanation: Mefloquine 250 mg weekly is given for chemoprophylaxis against malaria in adults. It should beadministered 2-3 weeks before travelling.Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for travellers from non-endemic areas and as a short termmeasure for soldiers, police and labour forces serving in highly endemic areas. It should becomplemented by personal protection and vector control.The following drugs are used for malaria chemoprophylaxis:•-Chloroquine 300 mg/week•Proguanil 200mg/day•Mefloquine 250mg/week-Doxycycline 100mg/dayMefloquine is contraindicated in cases with a history of convulsions, neuropsychiatric problemsand cardiac conditions.

questions.question: What is the most important strategy for the control of malaria in endemic areas?
questions.explanation: Vector control is the most important strategy to control malaria in endemic areas. Propermeasures should be taken to kill both adult mosquitoes and larvae.

questions.question: Which of the following was a component of the Roll back malaria programme?

options.C: Development of larvivorous fish for eradication of larvae

questions.explanation: Ensuring proper and expanded use of insecticide-treated mosquito nets was a component of theRoll Back Malaria (RBM) programme.The other components of the RBM initiative included:•Strengthening the health system to ensure better delivery of health care•Ensuring adequate access to basic health care and training of health workers•Encouraging the development of more effective and new anti-malaria drugs275

questions.question: Which sequence of infection poses the highest risk of dengue hemorrhagic fever?
questions.explanation: The DENV-1 --> DENV-2 sequence of infection is associated with the highest risk of denguehemorrhagic fever (DHF).Multiple infections with different serotypes of the dengue virus lead to severe forms of denguesuch as DHF/DSS. The first infection probably sensitizes the patient, while the second infectionwith a different serotype appears to produce immunological catastrophe.• DENV-1 --> DENV-2 - 500-fold risk (compared to primary infection alone)• DENV-3 --> DENV-2 - 150-fold risk• DENV-4 --> DENV-2 - 50-fold risk

questions.question: 269What is the extrinsic incubation period of the dengue virus?
questions.explanation: The extrinsic incubation period of the dengue virus is 8-10 days. This refers to the periodnecessary for the development of the disease agent in the arthropod host.Aedes mosquitoes become infective when they feed on infected patients from 1 day before onset ofillness to the 5th day (viremia stage) of illness. After 8-10 days of extrinsic incubation of the virusin a mosquito, Aedes becomes infective and can transmit the infection. Highertemperature results in shortening of the extrinsic incubation period, allowing mosquitoes toremain infectious for a longer duration.

questions.question: What is the cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs?
questions.explanation: The primary modality of treatment in patients with dengue with warning signs is IV fluids.The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion andthereby shock. Warning signs in dengue include:•Abdominal pain or tenderness• Persistent vomiting•Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)• Mucosal bleeding• Lethargy or restlessness•• Hepatomegaly >2 cm•Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet countInpatient management is advised to all patients of dengue with warning signs. The managementof dengue includes:•⚫ IV crystalloids - mainstay of treatment276• Platelet transfusion - severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleedingFFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred for treatment in dengue.

questions.question: In patients with dengue fever, platelets should be transfused if the platelet count falls belowwhich of the following?
questions.explanation: Prophylactic platelet transfusion in dengue is to be initiated when the platelet count is<10,000/cu.mm.Indications for platelet transfusion in dengue are as follows:• Platelet count <10,000/cu.mm•Prolonged shock with coagulopathySystemic massive bleeding

questions.question: When can a patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock be discharged?

options.A: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.explanation: A patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock can be discharged after the return of appetite.Criteria for the discharge of patients recovering from dengue:•••Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugsPlatelet count >50,000/cu.mm• Return of appetite•Adequate urine output• Visible clinical improvement• Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock• No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.question: 270Which of the following is a WHO-approved dengue vaccine for individuals seropositive fordengue virus?
questions.explanation: Dengvaxia is a WHO-approved vaccine for individuals seropositive for dengue virus. It is currentlylicensed in 20 countries.A pre-vaccination screening strategy must be adopted so that only dengue-seropositive individualsare vaccinated. It is indicated for individuals between 9 to 16 years. It is given in 3 doses, 6months apart. Booster doses are not required.However, it carries an increased risk of severe dengue in those who experience their first naturaldengue infection after vaccination (seronegative individuals).Note: TV003, a live, attenuated, tetravalent dengue vaccine is currently in Phase-3 trials. It hasshown efficacy in promoting immunity in both seropositive and seronegative individuals between2-59 years of age.277

questions.question: The prepatent period in lymphatic filariasis is the time interval between:

options.A: Invasion of infective larvae and blockage of lymphatics
options.B: Inoculation of infective larvae and detection of microfilaria
options.C: Ingestion of microfilaria and development of third stage larva
options.D: Inoculation of infective larvae and maturation into adult worm

questions.explanation: The prepatent period in lymphatic filariasis is the time interval between inoculation of theinfective larvae and the first appearance of detectable microfilaria.The clinical incubation period is the time interval from the invasion of infective larvae and thedevelopment of clinical manifestations. It is usually 8-16 months.

questions.question: A 44-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, chills, and pain in his groin area.Examination revealed reddish streaks over his lower limbs and bilateral non-pitting edema tothe level of the knee. Swelling and tenderness in his scrotum was also noted. To diagnose thecondition, when will you draw blood from the patient?
questions.explanation: This patient has features of lymphangitis, lymphedema, and epididymo-orchitis, which aresuggestive of acute filariasis. Blood must be drawn between 10 pm to 2 am. This is because themaximum density of microfilaria are present in the peripheral blood at this time.

questions.question: Which is the most sensitive method to detect low-density microfilaremia in blood?
questions.explanation: The most sensitive method to detect low-density microfilaremia in the blood is by membrane filterconcentration.The thick film is the most commonly used method for epidemiological assessment. The DECprovocative test is used to induce microfilaria to appear in the blood in the daytime.

questions.question: What is the dose of diethylcarbamazine for the treatment of Bancroftian filariasis?
questions.explanation: The dose of diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for treatment of Bancroftian filariasis is 6 mg/kg/day orallyfor 12 days.Medicated common salt with 1-4g DEC/kg is a special form of mass treatment, particularly inendemic areas. By this method, very low doses of DEC are given over a long period of time.278
